quoteText: Hamidullah, Hamidullah! am I late?
subQuotationList: ['Hamidullah, Hamidullah! am I late?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Do not apologize, You are always late.
subQuotationList: ['Do not apologize,', 'You are always late.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
Kindly answer my question. Am I late? Has Mahmoud Ali eaten all
the food? If so I go elsewhere. Mr. Mahmoud Ali, how are you?
subQuotationList: ['Kindly answer my question. Am I late? Has Mahmoud Ali eaten all\nthe food? If so I go elsewhere. Mr. Mahmoud Ali, how are you?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Thank you, Dr. Aziz, I am dying.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, Dr. Aziz, I am dying.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText: Dying before your dinner? Oh, poor Mahmoud Ali!
subQuotationList: ['Dying before your dinner? Oh, poor Mahmoud Ali!']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
Hamidullah here is actually dead. He passed away just as you rode
up on your bike.
subQuotationList: ['Hamidullah here is actually dead. He passed away just as you rode\nup on your bike.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText:
Yes, that is so, Imagine us both as addressing
you from another and a happier world.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that is so,', 'Imagine us both as addressing\nyou from another and a happier world.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
Does there happen to be such a thing as a hookah in that happier
world of yours?
subQuotationList: ['Does there happen to be such a thing as a hookah in that happier\nworld of yours?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Aziz, don't chatter. We are having a very sad talk.
subQuotationList: ["Aziz, don't chatter. We are having a very sad talk."]
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText: Well, look at my own experience this morning.
subQuotationList: ['Well, look at my own experience this morning.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText: I only contend that it is possible in England,
subQuotationList: ['I only contend that it is possible in England,']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
It is impossible here. Aziz! The red-nosed boy has again insulted
me in Court. I do not blame him. He was told that he ought to
insult me. Until lately he was quite a nice boy, but the others
have got hold of him.
subQuotationList:
['It is impossible here. Aziz! The red-nosed boy has again insulted
me in Court. I do not blame him. He was told that he ought to
insult me. Until lately he was quite a nice boy, but the others
have got hold of him.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr. Aziz'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop']]]

quoteText:
Yes, they have no chance here, that is my point. They come out
intending to be gentlemen, and are told it will not do. Look at
Lesley, look at Blakiston, now it is your red-nosed boy, and
Fielding will go next. Why, I remember when Turton came out first.
It was in another part of the Province. You fellows will not
believe me, but I have driven with Turton in his carriage   Turton!
Oh yes, we were once quite intimate. He has shown me his stamp
collection.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, they have no chance here, that is my point. They come out
intending to be gentlemen, and are told it will not do. Look at
Lesley, look at Blakiston, now it is your red-nosed boy, and
Fielding will go next. Why, I remember when Turton came out first.
It was in another part of the Province. You fellows will not
believe me, but I have driven with Turton in his carriage   Turton!
Oh yes, we were once quite intimate. He has shown me his stamp
collection.']
speaker: Hamidullah
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Mahmoud Ali', 'Dr. Aziz'], ['Mr. Turton'], ['Mr. Turton'], ['Mr. Turton'], ['Hamidullah', 'Mr. Turton'], ['Mr. Turton'], ['Mr. Turton']]]

quoteText:
He would expect you to steal it now. Turton! But red-nosed boy
will be far worse than Turton!
subQuotationList: ['He would expect you to steal it now. Turton! But red-nosed boy\nwill be far worse than Turton!']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText:
I do not think so. They all become exactly the same, not worse,
not better. I give any Englishman two years, be he Turton or
Burton. It is only the difference of a letter. And I give any
Englishwoman six months. All are exactly alike. Do you not agree
with me?
subQuotationList:
['I do not think so. They all become exactly the same, not worse,
not better. I give any Englishman two years, be he Turton or
Burton. It is only the difference of a letter. And I give any
Englishwoman six months. All are exactly alike. Do you not agree
with me?']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
I do not, For
my own part I find such profound differences among our rulers.
Red-nose mumbles, Turton talks distinctly, Mrs. Turton takes
bribes, Mrs. Red-nose does not and cannot, because so far there is
no Mrs. Red-nose.
subQuotationList:
['I do not,', 'For
my own part I find such profound differences among our rulers.
Red-nose mumbles, Turton talks distinctly, Mrs. Turton takes
bribes, Mrs. Red-nose does not and cannot, because so far there is
no Mrs. Red-nose.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText: Bribes?
subQuotationList: ['Bribes?']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
Did you not know that when they were lent to Central India over
a Canal Scheme, some Rajah or other gave her a sewing machine in
solid gold so that the water should run through his state.
subQuotationList: ['Did you not know that when they were lent to Central India over\na Canal Scheme, some Rajah or other gave her a sewing machine in\nsolid gold so that the water should run through his state.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText: And does it?
subQuotationList: ['And does it?']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
No, that is where Mrs. Turton is so skilful. When we poor blacks
take bribes, we perform what we are bribed to perform, and the law
discovers us in consequence. The English take and do nothing. I
admire them.
subQuotationList:
['No, that is where Mrs. Turton is so skilful. When we poor blacks
take bribes, we perform what we are bribed to perform, and the law
discovers us in consequence. The English take and do nothing. I
admire them.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText: We all admire them. Aziz, please pass me the hookah.
subQuotationList: ['We all admire them. Aziz, please pass me the hookah.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText: Oh, not yet   hookah is so jolly now.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, not yet   hookah is so jolly now.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: You are a very selfish boy.
subQuotationList: ['You are a very selfish boy.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
But take my case   the case of young Hugh Bannister. Here is the
son of my dear, my dead friends, the Reverend and Mrs. Bannister,
whose goodness to me in England I shall never forget or describe.
They were father and mother to me, I talked to them as I do now.
In the vacations their Rectory became my home. They entrusted all
their children to me   I often carried little Hugh about   I took him
up to the Funeral of Queen Victoria, and held him in my arms above
the crowd.
subQuotationList:
['But take my case   the case of young Hugh Bannister. Here is the
son of my dear, my dead friends, the Reverend and Mrs. Bannister,
whose goodness to me in England I shall never forget or describe.
They were father and mother to me, I talked to them as I do now.
In the vacations their Rectory became my home. They entrusted all
their children to me   I often carried little Hugh about   I took him
up to the Funeral of Queen Victoria, and held him in my arms above
the crowd.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText: Queen Victoria was different,
subQuotationList: ['Queen Victoria was different,']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText:
I learn now that this boy is in business as a leather merchant at
Cawnpore. Imagine how I long to see him and to pay his fare that
this house may be his home. But it is useless. The other
Anglo-Indians will have got hold of him long ago. He will probably
think that I want something, and I cannot face that from the son
of my old friends. Oh, what in this country has gone wrong with
everything, Vakil Sahib? I ask you.
subQuotationList:
['I learn now that this boy is in business as a leather merchant at
Cawnpore. Imagine how I long to see him and to pay his fare that
this house may be his home. But it is useless. The other
Anglo-Indians will have got hold of him long ago. He will probably
think that I want something, and I cannot face that from the son
of my old friends. Oh, what in this country has gone wrong with
everything, Vakil Sahib? I ask you.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
Why talk about the English? Brrrr . . . ! Why be
either friends with the fellows or not friends? Let us shut them
out and be jolly. Queen Victoria and Mrs. Bannister were the only
exceptions, and they're dead.
subQuotationList:
["Why talk about the English? Brrrr . . . ! Why be
either friends with the fellows or not friends? Let us shut them
out and be jolly. Queen Victoria and Mrs. Bannister were the only
exceptions, and they're dead."]
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: No, no, I do not admit that, I have met others.
subQuotationList: ['No, no, I do not admit that, I have met others.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
So have I, All ladies
are far from alike.
subQuotationList: ['So have I,', 'All ladies\nare far from alike.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText: She said
subQuotationList: ['She said']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
in
the most natural way.
subQuotationList: ['in\nthe most natural way.']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
She offered me a lozenge when the dust
irritated my throat.
subQuotationList: ['She offered me a lozenge when the dust\nirritated my throat.']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
But of course all this is
exceptional. The exception does not prove the rule. The average
woman is like Mrs. Turton, and, Aziz, you know what she is.
subQuotationList: ['But of course all this is\nexceptional. The exception does not prove the rule. The average\nwoman is like Mrs. Turton, and, Aziz, you know what she is.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText:
Come and see my wife a little
then,
subQuotationList: ['Come and see my wife a little\nthen,']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText: Once is enough.
subQuotationList: ['Once is enough.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
Yes, he has done his duty, Do not tease him
so. He carries on his family, two boys and their sister.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, he has done his duty,', 'Do not tease him\nso. He carries on his family, two boys and their sister.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
Aunt, they live most comfortably with my wife's mother, where she
was living when she died. I can see them whenever I like. They are
such very, very small children.
subQuotationList: ["Aunt, they live most comfortably with my wife's mother, where she\nwas living when she died. I can see them whenever I like. They are\nsuch very, very small children."]
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
And he sends them the whole of his salary and lives like a
low-grade clerk, and tells no one the reason. What more do you
require him to do?
subQuotationList: ['And he sends them the whole of his salary and lives like a\nlow-grade clerk, and tells no one the reason. What more do you\nrequire him to do?']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
What is to become of all our daughters if men refuse
to marry? They will marry beneath them, or
subQuotationList: ['What is to become of all our daughters if men refuse\nto marry? They will marry beneath them, or']
speaker: Hamidullah Begum

quoteText:
Perhaps
. . . but later . . .
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps\n. . . but later . . .']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
You mustn't put off what you think right, That
is why India is in such a plight, because we put off things.
subQuotationList: ["You mustn't put off what you think right,", 'That\nis why India is in such a plight, because we put off things.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText: Old Callendar wants to see me at his bungalow, He might have the politeness to say why.
subQuotationList: ['Old Callendar wants to see me at his bungalow,', 'He might have the politeness to say why.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Some case, I daresay.
subQuotationList: ['Some case, I daresay.']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
I daresay not, I daresay nothing. He has found out our dinner
hour, that's all, and chooses to interrupt us every time, in order
to show his power.
subQuotationList: ["I daresay not, I daresay nothing. He has found out our dinner\nhour, that's all, and chooses to interrupt us every time, in order\nto show his power."]
speaker: Dr. Aziz
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Major Callendar'], ['Mahmoud Ali', 'Hamidullah', 'Dr. Aziz'], ['Mahmoud Ali', 'Hamidullah', 'Dr. Aziz'], ['Major Callendar']]]

quoteText:
On the one hand he always does this, on the other it may be a
serious case, and you cannot know, Had you not better clean your
teeth after pan?
subQuotationList: ['On the one hand he always does this, on the other it may be a\nserious case, and you cannot know,', 'Had you not better clean your\nteeth after pan?']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText:
If my teeth are to be cleaned, I don't go at all. I am an Indian,
it is an Indian habit to take pan. The Civil Surgeon must put up
with it. Mohammed Latif, my bike, please.
subQuotationList: ["If my teeth are to be cleaned, I don't go at all. I am an Indian,\nit is an Indian habit to take pan. The Civil Surgeon must put up\nwith it. Mohammed Latif, my bike, please."]
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Aziz, Aziz, imprudent boy. . . .
subQuotationList: ['Aziz, Aziz, imprudent boy. . . .']
speaker: Hamidullah

quoteText: But the sahib has left me some message?
subQuotationList: ['But the sahib has left me some message?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: No.
speaker: The Servant

quoteText: Mrs. Lesley, it _is_ a tonga,
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Lesley, it _is_ a tonga,']
speaker: Mrs. Callendar

quoteText: Ours?
subQuotationList: ['Ours?']
speaker: Mrs. Lesley

quoteText: Take the gifts the gods provide, anyhow,
subQuotationList: ['Take the gifts the gods provide, anyhow,']
speaker: Mrs. Lesley

quoteText: O Tonga wallah, club, club. Why doesn't the fool go?
subQuotationList: ["O Tonga wallah, club, club. Why doesn't the fool go?"]
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText: Go, I will pay you to-morrow, You are most welcome, ladies.
subQuotationList: ['Go, I will pay you to-morrow,', 'You are most welcome, ladies.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Saying nothing?
subQuotationList: ['Saying nothing?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Then I will write him a letter.
subQuotationList: ['Then I will write him a letter.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
Tell him I have called, that is
sufficient,
subQuotationList: ['Tell him I have called, that is\nsufficient,']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
Here is my card.
Call me a tonga.
subQuotationList: ['Here is my card.\nCall me a tonga.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Huzoor, all are at the club.
subQuotationList: ['Huzoor, all are at the club.']
speaker: The Servant

quoteText: Then telephone for one down to the railway station.
subQuotationList: ['Then telephone for one down to the railway station.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
Enough, enough, I prefer to
walk.
subQuotationList: ['Enough, enough, I prefer to\nwalk.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
Madam!
Madam! Madam!
subQuotationList: ['Madam!\nMadam! Madam!']
speaker: Dr. Aziz
referringExpression: he was furiously angry and shouted

quoteText: Oh! Oh!
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Oh!']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Madam, this is a mosque, you have no right here at all; you should
have taken off your shoes; this is a holy place for Moslems.
subQuotationList: ['Madam, this is a mosque, you have no right here at all; you should\nhave taken off your shoes; this is a holy place for Moslems.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: I have taken them off.
subQuotationList: ['I have taken them off.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: You have?
subQuotationList: ['You have?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: I left them at the entrance.
subQuotationList: ['I left them at the entrance.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Then I ask your pardon.
subQuotationList: ['Then I ask your pardon.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: I am truly sorry for speaking.
subQuotationList: ['I am truly sorry for speaking.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Yes, I was right, was I not? If I remove my shoes, I am allowed?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I was right, was I not? If I remove my shoes, I am allowed?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Of course, but so few ladies take the trouble, especially if
thinking no one is there to see.
subQuotationList: ['Of course, but so few ladies take the trouble, especially if\nthinking no one is there to see.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: That makes no difference. God is here.
subQuotationList: ['That makes no difference. God is here.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Madam!
subQuotationList: ['Madam!']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Please let me go.
subQuotationList: ['Please let me go.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Oh, can I do you some service now or at any time?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, can I do you some service now or at any time?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: No, thank you, really none   good night.
subQuotationList: ['No, thank you, really none   good night.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: May I know your name?
subQuotationList: ['May I know your name?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Mrs. Moore.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Moore.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Mrs.
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
Mrs. Moore, I am afraid I startled you. I shall tell my
community   our friends   about you. That God is here   very good, very
fine indeed. I think you are newly arrived in India.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Moore, I am afraid I startled you. I shall tell my\ncommunity   our friends   about you. That God is here   very good, very\nfine indeed. I think you are newly arrived in India.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Yes   how did you know?
subQuotationList: ['Yes   how did you know?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: By the way you address me. No, but can I call you a carriage?
subQuotationList: ['By the way you address me. No, but can I call you a carriage?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
I have only come from the club. They are doing a play that I have
seen in London, and it was so hot.
subQuotationList: ['I have only come from the club. They are doing a play that I have\nseen in London, and it was so hot.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: What was the name of the play?
subQuotationList: ['What was the name of the play?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Cousin Kate.
subQuotationList: ['Cousin Kate.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
I think you ought not to walk at night alone, Mrs. Moore. There
are bad characters about and leopards may come across from the
Marabar Hills. Snakes also.
subQuotationList: ['I think you ought not to walk at night alone, Mrs. Moore. There\nare bad characters about and leopards may come across from the\nMarabar Hills. Snakes also.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
For example, a six-spot beetle, You pick it up,
it bites, you die.
subQuotationList: ['For example, a six-spot beetle,', 'You pick it up,\nit bites, you die.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: But you walk about yourself.
subQuotationList: ['But you walk about yourself.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Oh, I am used to it.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I am used to it.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Used to snakes?
subQuotationList: ['Used to snakes?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
I'm a doctor, Snakes don't dare bite
me. Please may I ask you a question now? Why do
you come to India at this time of year, just as the cold weather
is ending?
subQuotationList:
["I'm a doctor,", "Snakes don't dare bite
me.", 'Please may I ask you a question now? Why do
you come to India at this time of year, just as the cold weather
is ending?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: I intended to start earlier, but there was an unavoidable delay.
subQuotationList: ['I intended to start earlier, but there was an unavoidable delay.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
It will soon be so unhealthy for you! And why ever do you come to
Chandrapore?
subQuotationList: ['It will soon be so unhealthy for you! And why ever do you come to\nChandrapore?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: To visit my son. He is the City Magistrate here.
subQuotationList: ['To visit my son. He is the City Magistrate here.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Oh no, excuse me, that is quite impossible. Our City Magistrate's
name is Mr. Heaslop. I know him intimately.
subQuotationList: ["Oh no, excuse me, that is quite impossible. Our City Magistrate's\nname is Mr. Heaslop. I know him intimately."]
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: He's my son all the same,
subQuotationList: ["He's my son all the same,"]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: But, Mrs. Moore, how can he be?
subQuotationList: ['But, Mrs. Moore, how can he be?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: I was married twice.
subQuotationList: ['I was married twice.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Yes, now I see, and your first husband died.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, now I see, and your first husband died.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: He did, and so did my second husband.
subQuotationList: ['He did, and so did my second husband.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Then we are in the same box, Then is the
City Magistrate the entire of your family now?
subQuotationList: ['Then we are in the same box,', 'Then is the\nCity Magistrate the entire of your family now?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: No, there are the younger ones   Ralph and Stella in England.
subQuotationList: ['No, there are the younger ones   Ralph and Stella in England.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: And the gentleman here, is he Ralph and Stella's half-brother?
subQuotationList: ["And the gentleman here, is he Ralph and Stella's half-brother?"]
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Quite right.
subQuotationList: ['Quite right.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Mrs. Moore, this is all extremely strange, because like yourself
I have also two sons and a daughter. Is not this the same box with
a vengeance?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Moore, this is all extremely strange, because like yourself\nI have also two sons and a daughter. Is not this the same box with\na vengeance?']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: What are their names? Not also Ronny, Ralph, and Stella, surely?
subQuotationList: ['What are their names? Not also Ronny, Ralph, and Stella, surely?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
No, indeed. How funny it sounds!
Their names are quite different and will surprise you. Listen,
please. I am about to tell you my children's names. The first is
called Ahmed, the second is called Karim, the third   she is the
eldest   Jamila. Three children are enough. Do not you agree with
me?
subQuotationList:
["No, indeed. How funny it sounds!
Their names are quite different and will surprise you. Listen,
please. I am about to tell you my children's names. The first is
called Ahmed, the second is called Karim, the third   she is the
eldest   Jamila. Three children are enough. Do not you agree with
me?"]
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: I do.
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Would you care to see over the Minto Hospital one morning? I have nothing else to offer at Chandrapore.
subQuotationList: ['Would you care to see over the Minto Hospital one morning?', 'I have nothing else to offer at Chandrapore.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
Thank you, I have seen it already, or I should have liked to come
with you very much.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, I have seen it already, or I should have liked to come\nwith you very much.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: I suppose the Civil Surgeon took you.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose the Civil Surgeon took you.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Yes, and Mrs. Callendar.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, and Mrs. Callendar.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Ah! A very charming lady.
subQuotationList: ['Ah! A very charming lady.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Possibly, when one knows her better.
subQuotationList: ['Possibly, when one knows her better.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: What? What? You didn't like her?
subQuotationList: ["What? What? You didn't like her?"]
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
She was certainly intending to be kind, but I did not find her
exactly charming.
subQuotationList: ['She was certainly intending to be kind, but I did not find her\nexactly charming.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
She has just taken my tonga without my
permission   do you call that being charming?   and Major Callendar
interrupts me night after night from where I am dining with my
friends and I go at once, breaking up a most pleasant entertainment,
and he is not there and not even a message. Is this charming, pray?
But what does it matter? I can do nothing and he knows it. I am
just a subordinate, my time is of no value, the verandah is good
enough for an Indian, yes, yes, let him stand, and Mrs. Callendar
takes my carriage and cuts me dead . . .
subQuotationList:
['She has just taken my tonga without my
permission   do you call that being charming?   and Major Callendar
interrupts me night after night from where I am dining with my
friends and I go at once, breaking up a most pleasant entertainment,
and he is not there and not even a message. Is this charming, pray?
But what does it matter? I can do nothing and he knows it. I am
just a subordinate, my time is of no value, the verandah is good
enough for an Indian, yes, yes, let him stand, and Mrs. Callendar
takes my carriage and cuts me dead . . .']
speaker: Dr. Aziz
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Callendar'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Major Callendar'], ['Mahmoud Ali', 'Hamidullah', 'Dr. Aziz'], ['Major Callendar'], ['Major Callendar'], ['Major Callendar'], ['Mrs. Callendar']]]

quoteText:
You understand me, you know what others feel. Oh, if others
resembled you!
subQuotationList: ['You understand me, you know what others feel. Oh, if others\nresembled you!']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
I don't think I understand people
very well. I only know whether I like or dislike them.
subQuotationList: ["I don't think I understand people\nvery well. I only know whether I like or dislike them."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Then you are an Oriental.
subQuotationList: ['Then you are an Oriental.']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText: Indians are not allowed into the Chandrapore Club even as guests,
subQuotationList: ['Indians are not allowed into the Chandrapore Club even as guests,']
speaker: Dr. Aziz

quoteText:
I want to see
the _real_ India,
subQuotationList: ['I want to see\nthe _real_ India,']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I want to see it too, and I only wish we could. Apparently the
Turtons will arrange something for next Tuesday.
subQuotationList: ['I want to see it too, and I only wish we could. Apparently the\nTurtons will arrange something for next Tuesday.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
It'll end in an elephant ride, it always does. Look at this
evening. _Cousin Kate!_ Imagine, _Cousin Kate!_ But where have you
been off to? Did you succeed in catching the moon in the Ganges?
subQuotationList: ["It'll end in an elephant ride, it always does. Look at this\nevening. _Cousin Kate!_ Imagine, _Cousin Kate!_ But where have you\nbeen off to? Did you succeed in catching the moon in the Ganges?"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: I went to the mosque, but I did not catch the moon.
subQuotationList: ['I went to the mosque, but I did not catch the moon.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: The angle would have altered   she rises later.
subQuotationList: ['The angle would have altered   she rises later.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
Later and later, Let me think   we don't see the other side of the moon out here,
no.
subQuotationList: ['Later and later,', "Let me think   we don't see the other side of the moon out here,\nno."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Come, India's not as bad as all that, Other side of the earth, if you like, but we stick to the same
old moon.
subQuotationList: ["Come, India's not as bad as all that,", 'Other side of the earth, if you like, but we stick to the same\nold moon.']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
We aren't even seeing the other side of the world; that's our
complaint,
subQuotationList: ["We aren't even seeing the other side of the world; that's our\ncomplaint,"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Have a drink,
subQuotationList: ['Have a drink,']
speaker: Mr. Turton

quoteText:
Mrs. Moore   Miss
Quested   have a drink, have two drinks.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Moore   Miss\nQuested   have a drink, have two drinks.']
speaker: Mr. Turton

quoteText:
The long and the short of it is Heaslop's
a sahib; he's the type we want, he's one of us,
subQuotationList: ["The long and the short of it is Heaslop's\na sahib; he's the type we want, he's one of us,"]
speaker: Mr. Turton

quoteText:
Hear,
hear!
subQuotationList: ['Hear,\nhear!']
speaker: _unknowable
referringExpression: another civilian who was leaning over the billiard table said

quoteText: Adela, have a drink; mother, a drink.
subQuotationList: ['Adela, have a drink; mother, a drink.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
addressees: ['Mrs. Callendar', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText:
Fielding! how's one to see the
real India?
subQuotationList: ["Fielding! how's one to see the\nreal India?"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'Mrs. Moore']
referringExpression: he called out to another passerby

quoteText: Try seeing Indians,
subQuotationList: ['Try seeing Indians,']
speaker: Cyril Fielding
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: Who was that?
subQuotationList: ['Who was that?']
speaker: _unknowable
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: Our schoolmaster   Government College.
subQuotationList: ['Our schoolmaster   Government College.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
addressees: ['Mrs. Callendar', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: As if one could avoid seeing them,
subQuotationList: ['As if one could avoid seeing them,']
speaker: Mrs. Lesley
addressees: ['Mrs. Callendar', 'Adela Quested', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText:
I've avoided, Excepting my own servant, I've
scarcely spoken to an Indian since landing.
subQuotationList: ["I've avoided,", "Excepting my own servant, I've\nscarcely spoken to an Indian since landing."]
speaker: Adela Quested
addressees: ['Mrs. Callendar', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: Oh, lucky you.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, lucky you.']
speaker: Mrs. Lesley
addressees: ['Mrs. Callendar', 'Adela Quested', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: But I want to see them.
subQuotationList: ['But I want to see them.']
speaker: Adela Quested
addressees: ['Mrs. Callendar', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: Wanting to see Indians! How new that sounds!
subQuotationList: ['Wanting to see Indians! How new that sounds!']
speaker: _unknowable
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText:
Natives!
why, fancy!
subQuotationList: ['Natives!\nwhy, fancy!']
speaker: _unknowable
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText:
Let me explain. Natives
don't respect one any the more after meeting one, you see.
subQuotationList: ["Let me explain. Natives\ndon't respect one any the more after meeting one, you see."]
speaker: The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: That occurs after so many meetings.
subQuotationList: ['That occurs after so many meetings.']
speaker: Adela Quested
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText:
What I mean
is, I was a nurse before my marriage, and came across them a great
deal, so I know. I really do know the truth about Indians. A most
unsuitable position for any Englishwoman   I was a nurse in a Native
State. One's only hope was to hold sternly aloof.
subQuotationList:
["What I mean
is, I was a nurse before my marriage, and came across them a great
deal, so I know. I really do know the truth about Indians. A most
unsuitable position for any Englishwoman   I was a nurse in a Native
State. One's only hope was to hold sternly aloof."]
speaker: The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'Mrs. Moore']
referringExpression: the lady entirely stupid and friendly continued

quoteText: Even from one's patients?
subQuotationList: ["Even from one's patients?"]
speaker: Adela Quested
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: Why, the kindest thing one can do to a native is to let him die,
subQuotationList: ['Why, the kindest thing one can do to a native is to let him die,']
speaker: Mrs. Callendar
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: How if he went to heaven?
subQuotationList: ['How if he went to heaven?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse']

quoteText:
He can go where he likes as long as he doesn't come near me. They
give me the creeps.
subQuotationList: ["He can go where he likes as long as he doesn't come near me. They\ngive me the creeps."]
speaker: Mrs. Callendar
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText:
As a matter of fact I have thought what you were saying about
heaven, and that is why I am against Missionaries, I am all for Chaplains, but all against
Missionaries. Let me explain.
subQuotationList: ['As a matter of fact I have thought what you were saying about\nheaven, and that is why I am against Missionaries,', 'I am all for Chaplains, but all against\nMissionaries. Let me explain.']
speaker: The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'Mrs. Moore']
referringExpression: said the lady who had been a nurse

quoteText:
Do you really want to meet the Aryan Brother, Miss Quested? That
can be easily fixed up. I didn't realize he'd amuse you. You can practically see any type you like. Take
your choice. I know the Government people and the landowners,
Heaslop here can get hold of the barrister crew, while if you want
to specialize on education, we can come down on Fielding.
subQuotationList:
["Do you really want to meet the Aryan Brother, Miss Quested? That
can be easily fixed up. I didn't realize he'd amuse you.", 'You can practically see any type you like. Take
your choice. I know the Government people and the landowners,
Heaslop here can get hold of the barrister crew, while if you want
to specialize on education, we can come down on Fielding.']
speaker: Mr. Turton
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse', 'Mrs. Moore']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested']], [['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Cyril Fielding']]]

quoteText:
I'm tired of seeing picturesque figures pass before me as a
frieze, It was wonderful when we landed, but
that superficial glamour soon goes.
subQuotationList: ["I'm tired of seeing picturesque figures pass before me as a\nfrieze,", 'It was wonderful when we landed, but\nthat superficial glamour soon goes.']
speaker: Adela Quested
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText:
I only want those Indians whom you come across socially   as your
friends.
subQuotationList: ['I only want those Indians whom you come across socially   as your\nfriends.']
speaker: Adela Quested
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText:
Well, we don't come across them socially, They're full of all the virtues, but we don't, and it's now
eleven-thirty, and too late to go into the reasons.
subQuotationList: ["Well, we don't come across them socially,", "They're full of all the virtues, but we don't, and it's now\neleven-thirty, and too late to go into the reasons."]
speaker: Mr. Turton
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Mrs. Callendar', 'The Lady Who Had Been A Nurse', 'Mrs. Moore']

quoteText: Miss Quested, what a name!
subQuotationList: ['Miss Quested, what a name!']
speaker: Mrs. Turton
referringExpression: remarked Mrs Turton to her husband

quoteText:
India does wonders for the judgment, especially during the hot
weather; it has even done wonders for Fielding.
subQuotationList: ['India does wonders for the judgment, especially during the hot\nweather; it has even done wonders for Fielding.']
speaker: Mr. Turton

quoteText: It's decent of the Burra Sahib,
subQuotationList: ["It's decent of the Burra Sahib,"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Do you know
he's never given a Bridge Party before? Coming on top of the dinner
too! I wish I could have arranged something myself, but when you
know the natives better you'll realize it's easier for the Burra
Sahib than for me. They know him   they know he can't be fooled   I'm
still fresh comparatively. No one can even begin to think of
knowing this country until he has been in it twenty years.   Hullo,
the mater! Here's your cloak.   Well: for an example of the mistakes
one makes. Soon after I came out I asked one of the Pleaders to
have a smoke with me   only a cigarette, mind. I found afterwards
that he had sent touts all over the bazaar to announce the fact   told
all the litigants, Ever since then I've dropped
on him in Court as hard as I could. It's taught me a lesson, and
I hope him.
subQuotationList:
["Do you know
he's never given a Bridge Party before? Coming on top of the dinner
too! I wish I could have arranged something myself, but when you
know the natives better you'll realize it's easier for the Burra
Sahib than for me. They know him   they know he can't be fooled   I'm
still fresh comparatively. No one can even begin to think of
knowing this country until he has been in it twenty years.   Hullo,
the mater! Here's your cloak.   Well: for an example of the mistakes
one makes. Soon after I came out I asked one of the Pleaders to
have a smoke with me   only a cigarette, mind. I found afterwards
that he had sent touts all over the bazaar to announce the fact   told
all the litigants,", "Ever since then I've dropped
on him in Court as hard as I could. It's taught me a lesson, and
I hope him."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Adela Quested'], ['Mr. Turton'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Mr. Turton'], ['Mr. Turton'], ['Mr. Turton']], []]

quoteText:
Isn't the lesson that you should invite all the Pleaders to have
a smoke with you?
subQuotationList: ["Isn't the lesson that you should invite all the Pleaders to have\na smoke with you?"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
Perhaps, but time's limited and the flesh weak. I prefer my smoke
at the club amongst my own sort, I'm afraid.
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps, but time's limited and the flesh weak. I prefer my smoke\nat the club amongst my own sort, I'm afraid."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Why not ask the Pleaders to the club?
subQuotationList: ['Why not ask the Pleaders to the club?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Not allowed.
subQuotationList: ['Not allowed.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Oh, yes   that's where I got
to   that's where I've been.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, yes   that's where I got\nto   that's where I've been."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Been there when?
subQuotationList: ['Been there when?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Between the acts.
subQuotationList: ['Between the acts.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: But, mother, you can't do that sort of thing.
subQuotationList: ["But, mother, you can't do that sort of thing."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Can't mother?
subQuotationList: ["Can't mother?"]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
No, really not in this country. It's not done. There's the danger
from snakes for one thing. They are apt to lie out in the evening.
subQuotationList: ["No, really not in this country. It's not done. There's the danger\nfrom snakes for one thing. They are apt to lie out in the evening."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Ah yes, so the young man there said.
subQuotationList: ['Ah yes, so the young man there said.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
This sounds very romantic, You meet a young man in a mosque, and then never let me
know!
subQuotationList: ['This sounds very romantic,', 'You meet a young man in a mosque, and then never let me\nknow!']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I was going to tell you, Adela, but something changed the
conversation and I forgot. My memory grows deplorable.
subQuotationList: ['I was going to tell you, Adela, but something changed the\nconversation and I forgot. My memory grows deplorable.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Was he nice?
subQuotationList: ['Was he nice?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Very nice.
subQuotationList: ['Very nice.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Who was he?
subQuotationList: ['Who was he?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: A doctor. I don't know his name.
subQuotationList: ["A doctor. I don't know his name."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
A doctor? I know of no young doctor in Chandrapore. How odd! What
was he like?
subQuotationList: ['A doctor? I know of no young doctor in Chandrapore. How odd! What\nwas he like?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Rather small, with a little moustache and quick eyes. He called
out to me when I was in the dark part of the mosque   about my shoes.
That was how we began talking. He was afraid I had them on, but I
remembered luckily. He told me about his children, and then we
walked back to the club. He knows you well.
subQuotationList:
['Rather small, with a little moustache and quick eyes. He called
out to me when I was in the dark part of the mosque   about my shoes.
That was how we began talking. He was afraid I had them on, but I
remembered luckily. He told me about his children, and then we
walked back to the club. He knows you well.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr. Aziz'], ['Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Dr. Aziz'], ['Dr. Aziz'], ['Dr. Aziz'], ['Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Dr. Aziz'], ['Ronny Heaslop']]]

quoteText: I wish you had pointed him out to me. I can't make out who he is.
subQuotationList: ["I wish you had pointed him out to me. I can't make out who he is."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: He didn't come into the club. He said he wasn't allowed to.
subQuotationList: ["He didn't come into the club. He said he wasn't allowed to."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Oh, good gracious!
Not a Mohammedan? Why ever didn't you tell me you'd been talking
to a native? I was going all wrong.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, good gracious!\nNot a Mohammedan? Why ever didn't you tell me you'd been talking\nto a native? I was going all wrong."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
A Mohammedan! How perfectly magnificent! Ronny, isn't that like your mother? While we talk about seeing
the real India, she goes and sees it, and then forgets she's seen
it.
subQuotationList: ['A Mohammedan! How perfectly magnificent!', "Ronny, isn't that like your mother? While we talk about seeing\nthe real India, she goes and sees it, and then forgets she's seen\nit."]
speaker: Adela Quested
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore']]]

quoteText:
He
called to you in the mosque, did he? How? Impudently? What was he
doing there himself at that time of night?   No, it's not their
prayer time.
subQuotationList:
["He
called to you in the mosque, did he? How? Impudently? What was he
doing there himself at that time of night?   No, it's not their
prayer time."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
So he called to you over your
shoes. Then it was impudence. It's an old trick. I wish you had
had them on.
subQuotationList: ["So he called to you over your\nshoes. Then it was impudence. It's an old trick. I wish you had\nhad them on."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
I think it was impudence, but I don't know about a trick, His nerves were all on edge   I could tell from his
voice. As soon as I answered he altered.
subQuotationList: ["I think it was impudence, but I don't know about a trick,", 'His nerves were all on edge   I could tell from his\nvoice. As soon as I answered he altered.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: You oughtn't to have answered.
subQuotationList: ["You oughtn't to have answered."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Now look here, wouldn't you expect a
Mohammedan to answer if you asked him to take off his hat in
church?
subQuotationList: ['Now look here,', "wouldn't you expect a\nMohammedan to answer if you asked him to take off his hat in\nchurch?"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: It's different, it's different; you don't understand.
subQuotationList: ["It's different, it's different; you don't understand."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I know I don't, and I want to. What is the difference, please?
subQuotationList: ["I know I don't, and I want to. What is the difference, please?"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: There's your Ganges.
subQuotationList: ["There's your Ganges."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: It's not much of a dead body that gets down to Chandrapore.
subQuotationList: ["It's not much of a dead body that gets down to Chandrapore."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Crocodiles down in it too, how terrible!
subQuotationList: ['Crocodiles down in it too, how terrible!']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
What a terrible river!
what a wonderful river!
subQuotationList: ['What a terrible river!\nwhat a wonderful river!']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Aziz! what a charming name!
subQuotationList: ['Aziz! what a charming name!']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: So you and he had a talk. Did you gather he was well disposed?
subQuotationList: ['So you and he had a talk. Did you gather he was well disposed?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Yes, quite,
after the first moment.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, quite,\nafter the first moment.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
I meant, generally. Did he seem to tolerate us   the brutal
conqueror, the sundried bureaucrat, that sort of thing?
subQuotationList: ['I meant, generally. Did he seem to tolerate us   the brutal\nconqueror, the sundried bureaucrat, that sort of thing?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Oh, yes, I think so, except the Callendars   he doesn't care for
the Callendars at all.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, yes, I think so, except the Callendars   he doesn't care for\nthe Callendars at all."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Oh. So he told you that, did he? The Major will be interested. I
wonder what was the aim of the remark.
subQuotationList: ['Oh. So he told you that, did he? The Major will be interested. I\nwonder what was the aim of the remark.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Ronny, Ronny! you're never going to pass it on to Major Callendar?
subQuotationList: ["Ronny, Ronny! you're never going to pass it on to Major Callendar?"]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Yes, rather. I must, in fact!
subQuotationList: ['Yes, rather. I must, in fact!']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: But, my dear boy
subQuotationList: ['But, my dear boy']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
If the Major heard I was disliked by any native subordinate of
mine, I should expect him to pass it on to me.
subQuotationList: ['If the Major heard I was disliked by any native subordinate of\nmine, I should expect him to pass it on to me.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: But, my dear boy   a private conversation!
subQuotationList: ['But, my dear boy   a private conversation!']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Nothing's private in India. Aziz knew that when he spoke out, so
don't you worry. He had some motive in what he said. My personal
belief is that the remark wasn't true.
subQuotationList: ["Nothing's private in India. Aziz knew that when he spoke out, so\ndon't you worry. He had some motive in what he said. My personal\nbelief is that the remark wasn't true."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: How not true?
subQuotationList: ['How not true?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: He abused the Major in order to impress you.
subQuotationList: ['He abused the Major in order to impress you.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I don't know what you mean, dear.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know what you mean, dear."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
It's the educated native's latest dodge. They used to cringe, but
the younger generation believe in a show of manly independence.
They think it will pay better with the itinerant M.P. But whether
the native swaggers or cringes, there's always something behind
every remark he makes, always something, and if nothing else he's
trying to increase his izzat   in plain Anglo-Saxon, to score. Of
course there are exceptions.
subQuotationList:
["It's the educated native's latest dodge. They used to cringe, but
the younger generation believe in a show of manly independence.
They think it will pay better with the itinerant M.P. But whether
the native swaggers or cringes, there's always something behind
every remark he makes, always something, and if nothing else he's
trying to increase his izzat   in plain Anglo-Saxon, to score. Of
course there are exceptions."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: You never used to judge people like this at home.
subQuotationList: ['You never used to judge people like this at home.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: India isn't home,
subQuotationList: ["India isn't home,"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
I can't deny that what you say sounds very sensible,
but you really must not hand on to Major Callendar anything I have
told you about Doctor Aziz.
subQuotationList: ["I can't deny that what you say sounds very sensible,\nbut you really must not hand on to Major Callendar anything I have\ntold you about Doctor Aziz."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
In return
please don't talk about Aziz to Adela.
subQuotationList: ["In return\nplease don't talk about Aziz to Adela."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Not talk about him? Why?
subQuotationList: ['Not talk about him? Why?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
There you go again, mother   I really can't explain every thing. I
don't want Adela to be worried, that's the fact; she'll begin
wondering whether we treat the natives properly, and all that sort
of nonsense.
subQuotationList:
["There you go again, mother   I really can't explain every thing. I
don't want Adela to be worried, that's the fact; she'll begin
wondering whether we treat the natives properly, and all that sort
of nonsense."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore']]]

quoteText:
But she came out to be worried   that's exactly why she's here. She
discussed it all on the boat. We had a long talk when we went on
shore at Aden. She knows you in play, as she put it, but not in
work, and she felt she must come and look round, before she
decided   and before you decided. She is very, very fair-minded.
subQuotationList:
["But she came out to be worried   that's exactly why she's here. She
discussed it all on the boat. We had a long talk when we went on
shore at Aden. She knows you in play, as she put it, but not in
work, and she felt she must come and look round, before she
decided   and before you decided. She is very, very fair-minded."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Adela Quested']]]

quoteText: I know,
subQuotationList: ['I know,']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Pretty dear,
subQuotationList: ['Pretty dear,']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
It is owing to orders from the L.G., Turton would never do this unless compelled. Those high officials
are different   they sympathize, the Viceroy sympathizes, they would
have us treated properly. But they come too seldom and live too
far away. Meanwhile
subQuotationList:
['It is owing to orders from the L.G.,', 'Turton would never do this unless compelled. Those high officials
are different   they sympathize, the Viceroy sympathizes, they would
have us treated properly. But they come too seldom and live too
far away. Meanwhile']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText:
It is easy to sympathize at a distance, I value more the kind word that is spoken close to
my ear. Mr. Turton has spoken it, from whatever cause. He speaks,
we hear. I do not see why we need discuss it further.
subQuotationList: ['It is easy to sympathize at a distance,', 'I value more the kind word that is spoken close to\nmy ear. Mr. Turton has spoken it, from whatever cause. He speaks,\nwe hear. I do not see why we need discuss it further.']
speaker: The Nawab Badahur
referringExpression: said an old gentleman with a beard

quoteText:
We have not all your sweet nature, Nawab Bahadur, nor your
learning.
subQuotationList: ['We have not all your sweet nature, Nawab Bahadur, nor your\nlearning.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Nawab Badahur'], ['The Nawab Badahur'], ['The Nawab Badahur']]]

quoteText:
The Lieutenant-Governor may be my very good friend, but I give
him no trouble.
subQuotationList: ['The Lieutenant-Governor may be my very good friend, but I give\nhim no trouble.']
speaker: The Nawab Badahur

quoteText:
And all is over. But I can be a
thorn in Mr. Turton's flesh, and if he asks me I accept the
invitation. I shall come in from Dilkusha specially, though I have
to postpone other business.
subQuotationList:
["And all is over. But I can be a
thorn in Mr. Turton's flesh, and if he asks me I accept the
invitation. I shall come in from Dilkusha specially, though I have
to postpone other business."]
speaker: The Nawab Badahur

quoteText: You will make yourself chip,
subQuotationList: ['You will make yourself chip,']
speaker: Ram Chand
referringExpression: suddenly said a little black man

quoteText: Mr. Ram Chand!
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Ram Chand!']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText: Mr. Mahmoud Ali!
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Mahmoud Ali!']
speaker: Ram Chand

quoteText:
Mr. Ram Chand, the Nawab Bahadur can decide what is cheap without
our valuation, I think.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Ram Chand, the Nawab Bahadur can decide what is cheap without\nour valuation, I think.']
speaker: Mahmoud Ali

quoteText:
I do not expect I shall make myself cheap, I do not see why we should make ourselves
cheap. I do not see why we should. The invitation is worded very
graciously.
subQuotationList: ['I do not expect I shall make myself cheap,', 'I do not see why we should make ourselves\ncheap. I do not see why we should. The invitation is worded very\ngraciously.']
speaker: The Nawab Badahur
referringExpression: said the Nawab Bahadur to Mr Ram Chand

quoteText:
Till Tuesday, then, gentlemen all, when I hope we
may meet in the flower gardens of the club.
subQuotationList: ['Till Tuesday, then, gentlemen all, when I hope we\nmay meet in the flower gardens of the club.']
speaker: The Nawab Badahur
referringExpression: he repeated all that he had said before though at greater length ending up with

quoteText:
It is only just five, My husband will be up
from his office in a moment and start the thing. I have no idea
what we have to do. It's the first time we've ever given a party
like this at the club. Mr. Heaslop, when I'm dead and gone will
you give parties like this? It's enough to make the old type of
Burra Sahib turn in his grave.
subQuotationList:
['It is only just five,', "My husband will be up
from his office in a moment and start the thing. I have no idea
what we have to do. It's the first time we've ever given a party
like this at the club. Mr. Heaslop, when I'm dead and gone will
you give parties like this? It's enough to make the old type of
Burra Sahib turn in his grave."]
speaker: Mrs. Turton
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Turton'], ['Mr. Turton'], ['Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton'], ['Mrs. Turton', 'Mr. Turton'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop']]]

quoteText:
You wanted something not picturesque
and we've provided it, What do you
think of the Aryan Brother in a topi and spats?
subQuotationList: ["You wanted something not picturesque\nand we've provided it,", 'What do you\nthink of the Aryan Brother in a topi and spats?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
The great point to remember is that no one who's here matters;
those who matter don't come. Isn't that so, Mrs. Turton?
subQuotationList: ["The great point to remember is that no one who's here matters;\nthose who matter don't come. Isn't that so, Mrs. Turton?"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Absolutely true,
subQuotationList: ['Absolutely true,']
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText:
The educated Indians
will be no good to us if there's a row, it's simply not worth while
conciliating them, that's why they don't matter. Most of the people
you see are seditious at heart, and the rest 'ld run squealing.
The cultivator   he's another story. The Pathan   he's a man if you
like. But these people   don't imagine they're India.
subQuotationList:
["The educated Indians
will be no good to us if there's a row, it's simply not worth while
conciliating them, that's why they don't matter. Most of the people
you see are seditious at heart, and the rest 'ld run squealing.
The cultivator   he's another story. The Pathan   he's a man if you
like. But these people   don't imagine they're India."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
the sort of thing no white man could have
written,
subQuotationList: ['the sort of thing no white man could have\nwritten,']
speaker: Mrs. Lesley

quoteText: To work, Mary, to work,
subQuotationList: ['To work, Mary, to work,']
speaker: Mr. Turton

quoteText:
What do you want me to do? Oh, those
purdah women! I never thought any would come. Oh dear!
subQuotationList: ['What do you want me to do? Oh, those\npurdah women! I never thought any would come. Oh dear!']
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText: I consider they ought to come over to me.
subQuotationList: ['I consider they ought to come over to me.']
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText: Come along, Mary, get it over.
subQuotationList: ['Come along, Mary, get it over.']
speaker: Mr. Turton

quoteText:
I refuse to shake hands with any of the men, unless it has to be
the Nawab Bahadur.
subQuotationList: ['I refuse to shake hands with any of the men, unless it has to be\nthe Nawab Bahadur.']
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText: Whom have we so far?
subQuotationList: ['Whom have we so far?']
speaker: Mr. Turton

quoteText:
H'm! h'm! much
as one expected. We know why he's here, I think   over that contract,
and he wants to get the right side of me for Mohurram, and he's
the astrologer who wants to dodge the municipal building regulations,
and he's that Parsi, and he's   Hullo! there he goes   smash into our
hollyhocks. Pulled the left rein when he meant the right. All as
usual.
subQuotationList:
["H'm! h'm! much
as one expected. We know why he's here, I think   over that contract,
and he wants to get the right side of me for Mohurram, and he's
the astrologer who wants to dodge the municipal building regulations,
and he's that Parsi, and he's   Hullo! there he goes   smash into our
hollyhocks. Pulled the left rein when he meant the right. All as
usual."]
speaker: Mr. Turton

quoteText:
They ought never to have been allowed to drive in; it's so bad
for them, Why they come at all I don't know. They hate it as much
as we do. Talk to Mrs. McBryde. Her husband made her give purdah
parties until she struck.
subQuotationList:
["They ought never to have been allowed to drive in; it's so bad
for them,", "Why they come at all I don't know. They hate it as much
as we do. Talk to Mrs. McBryde. Her husband made her give purdah
parties until she struck."]
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText: This isn't a purdah party,
subQuotationList: ["This isn't a purdah party,"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Oh, really,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, really,']
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText: Do kindly tell us who these ladies are,
subQuotationList: ['Do kindly tell us who these ladies are,']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
You're superior to them, anyway. Don't forget that. You're superior
to everyone in India except one or two of the Ranis, and they're
on an equality.
subQuotationList: ["You're superior to them, anyway. Don't forget that. You're superior\nto everyone in India except one or two of the Ranis, and they're\non an equality."]
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText: Is that what you wanted?
subQuotationList: ['Is that what you wanted?']
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText:
Please tell these ladies that I wish we could speak their language,
but we have only just come to their country.
subQuotationList: ['Please tell these ladies that I wish we could speak their language,\nbut we have only just come to their country.']
speaker: Adela Quested
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Bhattacharya'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Bhattacharya']]]

quoteText: Perhaps we speak yours a little,
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps we speak yours a little,']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText: Why, fancy, she understands!
subQuotationList: ['Why, fancy, she understands!']
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText: Eastbourne, Piccadilly, High Park Corner,
subQuotationList: ['Eastbourne, Piccadilly, High Park Corner,']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText: Oh yes, they're English-speaking.
subQuotationList: ["Oh yes, they're English-speaking."]
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText: But now we can talk: how delightful!
subQuotationList: ['But now we can talk: how delightful!']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: She knows Paris also,
subQuotationList: ['She knows Paris also,']
speaker: Mr. Bhattacharya

quoteText: They pass Paris on the way, no doubt,
subQuotationList: ['They pass Paris on the way, no doubt,']
speaker: Mrs. Turton

quoteText:
The shorter lady, she is my wife, she is Mrs. Bhattacharya, The taller lady, she is my sister, she is Mrs.
Das.
subQuotationList: ['The shorter lady, she is my wife, she is Mrs. Bhattacharya,', 'The taller lady, she is my sister, she is Mrs.\nDas.']
speaker: Mr. Bhattacharya

quoteText:
I wonder whether you
would allow us to call on you some day.
subQuotationList: ['I wonder whether you\nwould allow us to call on you some day.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore
referringExpression: Mrs Moore had an impulse and said to Mrs Bhattacharya

quoteText: When?
subQuotationList: ['When?']
speaker: Mrs. Bhattacharya

quoteText: Whenever is convenient.
subQuotationList: ['Whenever is convenient.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: All days are convenient.
subQuotationList: ['All days are convenient.']
speaker: Mrs. Bhattacharya

quoteText: Thursday . . .
subQuotationList: ['Thursday . . .']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Most certainly.
subQuotationList: ['Most certainly.']
speaker: Mrs. Bhattacharya

quoteText:
We shall enjoy it greatly, it would be a real pleasure. What about
the time?
subQuotationList: ['We shall enjoy it greatly, it would be a real pleasure. What about\nthe time?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: All hours.
subQuotationList: ['All hours.']
speaker: Mrs. Bhattacharya

quoteText:
Tell us which you would prefer. We're quite strangers to your
country; we don't know when you have visitors,
subQuotationList: ["Tell us which you would prefer. We're quite strangers to your\ncountry; we don't know when you have visitors,"]
speaker: Adela Quested
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Bhattacharya'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Bhattacharya'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Bhattacharya']]]

quoteText:
We leave
for Calcutta to-day.
subQuotationList: ['We leave\nfor Calcutta to-day.']
speaker: Mrs. Bhattacharya

quoteText: Oh, do you?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, do you?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Oh, but if you do we shall find you gone.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, but if you do we shall find you gone.']
speaker: Adela Quested
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Bhattacharya', 'Mrs. Bhattacharya'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Mr. Bhattacharya', 'Mrs. Bhattacharya']]]

quoteText: Yes, yes, you come to us Thursday.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, you come to us Thursday.']
speaker: Mr. Bhattacharya

quoteText: But you'll be in Calcutta.
subQuotationList: ["But you'll be in Calcutta."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: No, no, we shall not.
subQuotationList: ['No, no, we shall not.']
speaker: Mr. Bhattacharya

quoteText: We expect you Thursday.
subQuotationList: ['We expect you Thursday.']
speaker: Mr. Bhattacharya

quoteText: Thursday . . .
subQuotationList: ['Thursday . . .']
speaker: Mrs. Bhattacharya

quoteText:
You can't have done such a dreadful thing as to put off going for
our sake?
subQuotationList: ["You can't have done such a dreadful thing as to put off going for\nour sake?"]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: No, of course not, we are not such people.
subQuotationList: ['No, of course not, we are not such people.']
speaker: Mr. Bhattacharya

quoteText:
I believe that you have. Oh, please   it distresses me beyond
words.
subQuotationList: ['I believe that you have. Oh, please   it distresses me beyond\nwords.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
I'ld like to come very much indeed, and so would Mrs. Moore, I
know.
subQuotationList: ["I'ld like to come very much indeed, and so would Mrs. Moore, I\nknow."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: I'm rather a hermit, you know.
subQuotationList: ["I'm rather a hermit, you know."]
speaker: Cyril Fielding

quoteText: Much the best thing to be in this place.
subQuotationList: ['Much the best thing to be in this place.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Owing to my work and so on, I don't get up much to the club.
subQuotationList: ["Owing to my work and so on, I don't get up much to the club."]
speaker: Cyril Fielding

quoteText:
I know, I know, and we never get down from it. I envy you being
with Indians.
subQuotationList: ['I know, I know, and we never get down from it. I envy you being\nwith Indians.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Do you care to meet one or two?
subQuotationList: ['Do you care to meet one or two?']
speaker: Cyril Fielding

quoteText:
Very, very much indeed; it's what I long for. This party to-day
makes me so angry and miserable. I think my countrymen out here
must be mad. Fancy inviting guests and not treating them properly!
You and Mr. Turton and perhaps Mr. McBryde are the only people who
showed any common politeness. The rest make me perfectly ashamed,
and it's got worse and worse.
subQuotationList:
["Very, very much indeed; it's what I long for. This party to-day
makes me so angry and miserable. I think my countrymen out here
must be mad. Fancy inviting guests and not treating them properly!
You and Mr. Turton and perhaps Mr. McBryde are the only people who
showed any common politeness. The rest make me perfectly ashamed,
and it's got worse and worse."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Oh, just what we wanted to hear. And do you know Doctor Aziz?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, just what we wanted to hear. And do you know Doctor Aziz?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I know all about him. I don't know him. Would you like him asked
too?
subQuotationList: ["I know all about him. I don't know him. Would you like him asked\ntoo?"]
speaker: Cyril Fielding

quoteText: Mrs. Moore says he is so nice.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Moore says he is so nice.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Very well, Miss Quested. Will Thursday suit you?
subQuotationList: ['Very well, Miss Quested. Will Thursday suit you?']
speaker: Cyril Fielding

quoteText:
Indeed it will, and that morning we go to this Indian lady's. All
the nice things are coming Thursday.
subQuotationList: ["Indeed it will, and that morning we go to this Indian lady's. All\nthe nice things are coming Thursday."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I won't ask the City Magistrate to bring you. I know he'll be busy
at that time.
subQuotationList: ["I won't ask the City Magistrate to bring you. I know he'll be busy\nat that time."]
speaker: Cyril Fielding

quoteText: Yes, Ronny is always hard-worked,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Ronny is always hard-worked,']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I should
never get like that,
subQuotationList: ['I should\nnever get like that,']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
If one couldn't see the laughable side of these people one
'ld be done for,
subQuotationList: ["If one couldn't see the laughable side of these people one\n'ld be done for,"]
speaker: Miss Derek

quoteText:
Oh, Nancy, how topping! Oh,
Nancy, how killing! I wish I could look at things like that.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Nancy, how topping! Oh,\nNancy, how killing! I wish I could look at things like that.']
speaker: Mrs. Mcbryde
referringExpression: Mrs McBryde it was she who had been the nurse ceased not to exclaim

quoteText:
Does Adela talk to you
much? I'm so driven with work, I don't see her as much
as I hoped, but I hope she finds things comfortable.
subQuotationList: ['Does Adela talk to you\nmuch?', "I'm so driven with work, I don't see her as much\nas I hoped, but I hope she finds things comfortable."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Adela and I talk mostly about India. Dear, since you mention it,
you're quite right   you ought to be more alone with her than you
are.
subQuotationList: ["Adela and I talk mostly about India. Dear, since you mention it,\nyou're quite right   you ought to be more alone with her than you\nare."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Adela Quested'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Ronny Heaslop']]]

quoteText: Yes, perhaps, but then people'ld gossip.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, perhaps, but then people'ld gossip."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Well, they must gossip sometime! Let them gossip.
subQuotationList: ['Well, they must gossip sometime! Let them gossip.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
People are so odd out here, and it's not like home   one's always
facing the footlights, as the Burra Sahib said. Take a silly little
example: when Adela went out to the boundary of the club compound,
and Fielding followed her. I saw Mrs. Callendar notice it. They
notice everything, until they're perfectly sure you're their sort.
subQuotationList:
["People are so odd out here, and it's not like home   one's always
facing the footlights, as the Burra Sahib said. Take a silly little
example: when Adela went out to the boundary of the club compound,
and Fielding followed her. I saw Mrs. Callendar notice it. They
notice everything, until they're perfectly sure you're their sort."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
I don't think Adela 'll ever be quite their sort   she's much too
individual.
subQuotationList: ["I don't think Adela 'll ever be quite their sort   she's much too\nindividual."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: I know, that's so remarkable about her,
subQuotationList: ["I know, that's so remarkable about her,"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I suppose nothing's on her mind,
subQuotationList: ["I suppose nothing's on her mind,"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Ask her, ask her yourself, my dear boy.
subQuotationList: ['Ask her, ask her yourself, my dear boy.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Probably she's heard tales of the heat, but of course I should
pack her off to the Hills every April   I'm not one to keep a wife
grilling in the Plains.
subQuotationList: ["Probably she's heard tales of the heat, but of course I should\npack her off to the Hills every April   I'm not one to keep a wife\ngrilling in the Plains."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Oh, it wouldn't be the weather.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, it wouldn't be the weather."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
There's nothing in India but the weather, my dear mother; it's
the Alpha and Omega of the whole affair.
subQuotationList: ["There's nothing in India but the weather, my dear mother; it's\nthe Alpha and Omega of the whole affair."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Yes, as Mr. McBryde was saying, but it's much more the Anglo-Indians
themselves who are likely to get on Adela's nerves. She doesn't
think they behave pleasantly to Indians, you see.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, as Mr. McBryde was saying, but it's much more the Anglo-Indians\nthemselves who are likely to get on Adela's nerves. She doesn't\nthink they behave pleasantly to Indians, you see."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
What did I tell you? I
knew it last week. Oh, how like a woman to worry over a side-issue!
subQuotationList: ['What did I tell you?', 'I\nknew it last week. Oh, how like a woman to worry over a side-issue!']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: A side-issue, a side-issue? How can it be that?
subQuotationList: ['A side-issue, a side-issue?', 'How can it be that?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: We're not out here for the purpose of behaving pleasantly!
subQuotationList: ["We're not out here for the purpose of behaving pleasantly!"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: What do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
What I say. We're out here to do justice and keep the peace.
Them's my sentiments. India isn't a drawing-room.
subQuotationList: ["What I say. We're out here to do justice and keep the peace.\nThem's my sentiments. India isn't a drawing-room."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Your sentiments are those of a god,
subQuotationList: ['Your sentiments are those of a god,']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: India likes gods.
subQuotationList: ['India likes gods.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: And Englishmen like posing as gods.
subQuotationList: ['And Englishmen like posing as gods.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
There's no point in all this. Here we are, and we're going to
stop, and the country's got to put up with us, gods or no gods.
Oh, look here, what do you
and Adela want me to do? Go against my class, against all the
people I respect and admire out here? Lose such power as I have
for doing good in this country because my behaviour isn't pleasant?
You neither of you understand what work is, or you 'ld never talk
such eyewash. I hate talking like this, but one must occasionally.
It's morbidly sensitive to go on as Adela and you do. I noticed
you both at the club to-day   after the Burra Sahib had been at all
that trouble to amuse you. I am out here to work, mind, to hold
this wretched country by force. I'm not a missionary or a Labour
Member or a vague sentimental sympathetic literary man. I'm just
a servant of the Government; it's the profession you wanted me to
choose myself, and that's that. We're not pleasant in India, and
we don't intend to be pleasant. We've something more important to
do.
subQuotationList:
["There's no point in all this. Here we are, and we're going to
stop, and the country's got to put up with us, gods or no gods.
Oh, look here,", "what do you
and Adela want me to do? Go against my class, against all the
people I respect and admire out here? Lose such power as I have
for doing good in this country because my behaviour isn't pleasant?
You neither of you understand what work is, or you 'ld never talk
such eyewash. I hate talking like this, but one must occasionally.
It's morbidly sensitive to go on as Adela and you do. I noticed
you both at the club to-day   after the Burra Sahib had been at all
that trouble to amuse you. I am out here to work, mind, to hold
this wretched country by force. I'm not a missionary or a Labour
Member or a vague sentimental sympathetic literary man. I'm just
a servant of the Government; it's the profession you wanted me to
choose myself, and that's that. We're not pleasant in India, and
we don't intend to be pleasant. We've something more important to
do."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore']]]

quoteText: I'm going to argue, and indeed dictate, The English are out here to be pleasant.
subQuotationList: ["I'm going to argue, and indeed dictate,", 'The English are out here to be pleasant.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: How do you make that out, mother?
subQuotationList: ['How do you make that out, mother?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Because India is part of the earth. And God has put us on the
earth in order to be pleasant to each other. God . . . is . . .
love.
subQuotationList: ['Because India is part of the earth. And God has put us on the\nearth in order to be pleasant to each other. God . . . is . . .\nlove.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
God has put us on earth to love our
neighbours and to show it, and He is omnipresent, even in India,
to see how we are succeeding.
subQuotationList: ['God has put us on earth to love our\nneighbours and to show it, and He is omnipresent, even in India,\nto see how we are succeeding.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
She is
certainly ageing, and I ought not to be vexed with anything she
says.
subQuotationList: ['She is\ncertainly ageing, and I ought not to be vexed with anything she\nsays.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
The desire to behave pleasantly satisfies God. . . The sincere if
impotent desire wins His blessing. I think every one fails, but
there are so many kinds of failure. Good will and more good will
and more good will. Though I speak with the tongues of . . .
subQuotationList:
['The desire to behave pleasantly satisfies God. . . The sincere if
impotent desire wins His blessing. I think every one fails, but
there are so many kinds of failure. Good will and more good will
and more good will. Though I speak with the tongues of . . .']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
I quite see
that. I suppose I ought to get off to my files now, and you'll be
going to bed.
subQuotationList: ["I quite see\nthat. I suppose I ought to get off to my files now, and you'll be\ngoing to bed."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
referringExpression: He waited until she had done and then said

quoteText: I suppose so, I suppose so.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose so, I suppose so.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
What can you
expect from the fellow? No grits, no
guts.
subQuotationList: ['What can you\nexpect from the fellow?', 'No grits, no\nguts.']
speaker: Major Callendar

quoteText:
