subQuotationList: ['Certainly.']
speaker: Mr. Turton
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText:
I am waiting for the verdict of the courts. If he is guilty I
resign from my service, and leave India. I resign from the club
now.
subQuotationList: ['I am waiting for the verdict of the courts. If he is guilty I\nresign from my service, and leave India. I resign from the club\nnow.']
speaker: Cyril Fielding
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Turton', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText: Hear, hear!
subQuotationList: ['Hear, hear!']
speaker: _unknowable
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Turton', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText:
You have not answered my question. Why did you not stand when Mr.
Heaslop entered?
subQuotationList: ['You have not answered my question. Why did you not stand when Mr.\nHeaslop entered?']
speaker: Mr. Turton
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText:
With all deference, sir, I am not here to answer questions, but
to make a personal statement, and I have concluded it.
subQuotationList: ['With all deference, sir, I am not here to answer questions, but\nto make a personal statement, and I have concluded it.']
speaker: Cyril Fielding
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Turton', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText: May I ask whether you have taken over charge of this District?
subQuotationList: ['May I ask whether you have taken over charge of this District?']
speaker: Mr. Turton
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText:
One moment, Mr. Fielding. You are not to go yet, please. Before
you leave the club, from which you do very well to resign, you will
express some detestation of the crime, and you will apologize to
Mr. Heaslop.
subQuotationList:
['One moment, Mr. Fielding. You are not to go yet, please. Before
you leave the club, from which you do very well to resign, you will
express some detestation of the crime, and you will apologize to
Mr. Heaslop.']
speaker: Mr. Turton
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'A Stray Subaltern']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Ronny Heaslop']]]

quoteText: Are you speaking to me officially, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Are you speaking to me officially, sir?']
speaker: Cyril Fielding
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Turton', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText:
Leave this room at once, and I deeply
regret that I demeaned myself to meet you at the station. You have
sunk to the level of your associates; you are weak, weak, that is
what is wrong with you
subQuotationList:
['Leave this room at once, and I deeply
regret that I demeaned myself to meet you at the station. You have
sunk to the level of your associates; you are weak, weak, that is
what is wrong with you']
speaker: Mr. Turton
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText:
I want to leave the room, but cannot while this gentleman prevents
me,
subQuotationList: ['I want to leave the room, but cannot while this gentleman prevents\nme,']
speaker: Cyril Fielding
addressees: ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Turton', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText: Let him go,
subQuotationList: ['Let him go,']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Turton', 'A Stray Subaltern']

quoteText: Fancy if I'd fallen or got angry,
subQuotationList: ["Fancy if I'd fallen or got angry,"]
speaker: Cyril Fielding

quoteText: In space things touch, in time things part,
subQuotationList: ['In space things touch, in time things part,']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I went into this
detestable cave, and I remember scratching
the wall with my finger-nail, to start the usual echo, and then as
I was saying there was this shadow, or sort of shadow, down the
entrance tunnel, bottling me up. It seemed like an age, but I
suppose the whole thing can't have lasted thirty seconds really.
I hit at him with the glasses, he pulled me round the cave by the
strap, it broke, I escaped, that's all. He never actually touched
me once. It all seems such nonsense. Naturally I'm upset, but I shall get over it.
subQuotationList:
['I went into this
detestable cave,', "and I remember scratching
the wall with my finger-nail, to start the usual echo, and then as
I was saying there was this shadow, or sort of shadow, down the
entrance tunnel, bottling me up. It seemed like an age, but I
suppose the whole thing can't have lasted thirty seconds really.
I hit at him with the glasses, he pulled me round the cave by the
strap, it broke, I escaped, that's all. He never actually touched
me once. It all seems such nonsense.", "Naturally I'm upset, but I shall get over it."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Can Mrs. Moore be with me?
subQuotationList: ['Can Mrs. Moore be with me?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
Certainly, and I shall be there myself, The case
won't come before me; they've objected to me on personal grounds.
It will be at Chandrapore   we thought at one time it would be
transferred elsewhere.
subQuotationList:
['Certainly, and I shall be there myself,', "The case
won't come before me; they've objected to me on personal grounds.
It will be at Chandrapore   we thought at one time it would be
transferred elsewhere."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Miss Quested realizes what all that means, though, The case will come before Das.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Quested realizes what all that means, though,', 'The case will come before Das.']
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde

quoteText: I must come before someone.
subQuotationList: ['I must come before someone.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
That's   that's the way to face it. You have the pluck, Miss
Quested.
subQuotationList: ["That's   that's the way to face it. You have the pluck, Miss\nQuested."]
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde

quoteText: the fruits of democracy.
subQuotationList: ['the fruits of democracy.']
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde

quoteText:
I do this less every day, I shall soon be quite
well,
subQuotationList: ['I do this less every day, I shall soon be quite\nwell,']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
What I need is something to do. That is why I keep on with this
ridiculous crying.
subQuotationList: ['What I need is something to do. That is why I keep on with this\nridiculous crying.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
It's not ridiculous, we think you wonderful, It only bothers us that we can't help you more.
Your stopping here   at such a time   is the greatest honour this
house
subQuotationList: ["It's not ridiculous, we think you wonderful,", "It only bothers us that we can't help you more.\nYour stopping here   at such a time   is the greatest honour this\nhouse"]
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mr. Mcbryde'], ['Adela Quested']], [['Mr. Mcbryde', 'Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Mr. Mcbryde'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested']]]

quoteText:
By the way, a letter
came here for you while you were ill, I opened it,
which is a strange confession to make. Will you forgive me? The
circumstances are peculiar. It is from Fielding.
subQuotationList:
['By the way, a letter
came here for you while you were ill,', 'I opened it,
which is a strange confession to make. Will you forgive me? The
circumstances are peculiar. It is from Fielding.']
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde

quoteText: Why should he write to me?
subQuotationList: ['Why should he write to me?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
A most lamentable thing has happened. The defence got hold of
him.
subQuotationList: ['A most lamentable thing has happened. The defence got hold of\nhim.']
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde

quoteText: He's a crank, a crank,
subQuotationList: ["He's a crank, a crank,"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
That's your way of putting it, but a man can be a crank without
being a cad. Miss Quested had better know how he behaved to you.
If you don't tell her, somebody else will. He is
now the mainstay of the defence, I needn't add. He is the one
righteous Englishman in a horde of tyrants. He receives deputations
from the bazaar, and they all chew betel nut and smear one another's
hands with scent. It is not easy to enter into the mind of such a
man. His students are on strike   out of enthusiasm for him they
won't learn their lessons. If it weren't for Fielding one would
never have had the Mohurram trouble. He has done a very grave
disservice to the whole community. The letter lay here a day or
two, waiting till you were well enough, then the situation got so
grave that I decided to open it in case it was useful to us.
subQuotationList:
["That's your way of putting it, but a man can be a crank without
being a cad. Miss Quested had better know how he behaved to you.
If you don't tell her, somebody else will.", "He is
now the mainstay of the defence, I needn't add. He is the one
righteous Englishman in a horde of tyrants. He receives deputations
from the bazaar, and they all chew betel nut and smear one another's
hands with scent. It is not easy to enter into the mind of such a
man. His students are on strike   out of enthusiasm for him they
won't learn their lessons. If it weren't for Fielding one would
never have had the Mohurram trouble. He has done a very grave
disservice to the whole community. The letter lay here a day or
two, waiting till you were well enough, then the situation got so
grave that I decided to open it in case it was useful to us."]
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Adela Quested'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Adela Quested']], [['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested', 'Mr. Mcbryde', 'Ronny Heaslop']]]

quoteText: Is it?
subQuotationList: ['Is it?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
Not at all. He only has the impertinence to suggest you have made
a mistake.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all. He only has the impertinence to suggest you have made\na mistake.']
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde

quoteText: Would that I had!
subQuotationList: ['Would that I had!']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
But think of his
behaviour to you, Ronny. When you had already to bear so much for
my sake! It was shocking of him. My dear, how can I repay you? How
can one repay when one has nothing to give? What is the use of
personal relationships when everyone brings less and less to them?
I feel we ought all to go back into the desert for centuries and
try and get good. I want to begin at the beginning. All the things
I thought I'd learnt are just a hindrance, they're not knowledge
at all. I'm not fit for personal relationships. Well, let's go,
let's go. Of course Mr. Fielding's letter doesn't count; he can
think and write what he likes, only he shouldn't have been rude to
you when you had so much to bear. That's what matters. . . . I
don't want your arm, I'm a magnificent walker, so don't touch me,
please.
subQuotationList:
["But think of his
behaviour to you, Ronny. When you had already to bear so much for
my sake! It was shocking of him. My dear, how can I repay you? How
can one repay when one has nothing to give? What is the use of
personal relationships when everyone brings less and less to them?
I feel we ought all to go back into the desert for centuries and
try and get good. I want to begin at the beginning. All the things
I thought I'd learnt are just a hindrance, they're not knowledge
at all. I'm not fit for personal relationships. Well, let's go,
let's go. Of course Mr. Fielding's letter doesn't count; he can
think and write what he likes, only he shouldn't have been rude to
you when you had so much to bear. That's what matters. . . . I
don't want your arm, I'm a magnificent walker, so don't touch me,
please."]
speaker: Adela Quested
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Cyril Fielding'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Mcbryde'], ['Ronny Heaslop', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Mcbryde'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Ronny Heaslop']]]

quoteText:
Oh,
we must help one another, we must take the rough with the smooth,
subQuotationList: ['Oh,\nwe must help one another, we must take the rough with the smooth,']
speaker: Mrs. Mcbryde

quoteText:
Mother's looking forward to
seeing you, but of course she's old, one mustn't forget that. Old
people never take things as one expects, in my opinion.
subQuotationList: ["Mother's looking forward to\nseeing you, but of course she's old, one mustn't forget that. Old\npeople never take things as one expects, in my opinion."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
What can I
do to make things easier for you? it's you who matter,
subQuotationList: ["What can I\ndo to make things easier for you? it's you who matter,"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Dear old girl to say so.
subQuotationList: ['Dear old girl to say so.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Dear old boy. Ronny, she isn't ill too?
subQuotationList: ['Dear old boy.', "Ronny, she isn't ill too?"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
But you'll find her   irritable. We are an irritable family. Well,
you'll see for yourself. No doubt my own nerves are out of order,
and I expected more from mother when I came in from the office than
she felt able to give. She is sure to make a special effort for
you; still, I don't want your home-coming to be a disappointing
one. Don't expect too much.
subQuotationList:
["But you'll find her   irritable. We are an irritable family. Well,
you'll see for yourself. No doubt my own nerves are out of order,
and I expected more from mother when I came in from the office than
she felt able to give. She is sure to make a special effort for
you; still, I don't want your home-coming to be a disappointing
one. Don't expect too much."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Adela Quested'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore', 'Ronny Heaslop'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Adela Quested']]]

quoteText: Here you are both back,
subQuotationList: ['Here you are both back,']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Are you all right? You appeared all right when I left,
subQuotationList: ['Are you all right? You appeared all right when I left,']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
I am all right, As a matter of fact I have
been looking at my return ticket. It is interchangeable, so I have
a much larger choice of boats home than I thought.
subQuotationList: ['I am all right,', 'As a matter of fact I have\nbeen looking at my return ticket. It is interchangeable, so I have\na much larger choice of boats home than I thought.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: We can go into that later, can't we?
subQuotationList: ["We can go into that later, can't we?"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Ralph and Stella may be wanting to know when I arrive.
subQuotationList: ['Ralph and Stella may be wanting to know when I arrive.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
There is plenty of time for all such plans. How do you think our
Adela looks?
subQuotationList: ['There is plenty of time for all such plans. How do you think our\nAdela looks?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
I am counting on you to help me through; it is such a blessing to
be with you again, everyone else is a stranger,
subQuotationList: ['I am counting on you to help me through; it is such a blessing to\nbe with you again, everyone else is a stranger,']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: I know it's all nothing; I must be sensible, I do try
subQuotationList: ["I know it's all nothing; I must be sensible, I do try"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I shouldn't mind if it had happened anywhere else; at least I
really don't know where it did happen.
subQuotationList: ["I shouldn't mind if it had happened anywhere else; at least I\nreally don't know where it did happen."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Yes, I mean that, at least not exactly; but there is this echo
that I keep on hearing.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I mean that, at least not exactly; but there is this echo\nthat I keep on hearing.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Oh, what of the echo?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, what of the echo?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: I can't get rid of it.
subQuotationList: ["I can't get rid of it."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: I don't suppose you ever will.
subQuotationList: ["I don't suppose you ever will."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Mrs. Moore, what is this echo?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Moore, what is this echo?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Don't you know?
subQuotationList: ["Don't you know?"]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
No   what is it? oh, do say! I felt you would be able to explain it
. . . this will comfort me so. . . .
subQuotationList: ['No   what is it? oh, do say! I felt you would be able to explain it\n. . . this will comfort me so. . . .']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: If you don't know, you don't know; I can't tell you.
subQuotationList: ["If you don't know, you don't know; I can't tell you."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: I think you're rather unkind not to say.
subQuotationList: ["I think you're rather unkind not to say."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Say, say, say,
subQuotationList: ['Say, say, say,']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
As if anything can
be said! I have spent my life in saying or in listening to sayings;
I have listened too much. It is time I was left in peace. Not to
die, No doubt you expect me to die, but when
I have seen you and Ronny married, and seen the other two and
whether they want to be married   I'll retire then into a cave of my
own. Somewhere where no young people will
come asking questions and expecting answers. Some shelf.
subQuotationList:
['As if anything can
be said! I have spent my life in saying or in listening to sayings;
I have listened too much. It is time I was left in peace. Not to
die,', "No doubt you expect me to die, but when
I have seen you and Ronny married, and seen the other two and
whether they want to be married   I'll retire then into a cave of my
own.", 'Somewhere where no young people will
come asking questions and expecting answers. Some shelf.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Quite so, but meantime a trial is coming on, and the notion of most of us is that we'd better pull together
and help one another through, instead of being disagreeable. Are
you going to talk like that in the witness-box?
subQuotationList: ['Quite so, but meantime a trial is coming on,', "and the notion of most of us is that we'd better pull together\nand help one another through, instead of being disagreeable. Are\nyou going to talk like that in the witness-box?"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Why should I be in the witness-box?
subQuotationList: ['Why should I be in the witness-box?']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: To confirm certain points in our evidence.
subQuotationList: ['To confirm certain points in our evidence.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I have nothing to do with your ludicrous law courts, I will not be dragged in at all.
subQuotationList: ['I have nothing to do with your ludicrous law courts,', 'I will not be dragged in at all.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
I won't have her dragged in, either; I won't have any more trouble
on my account, Her evidence is not the least essential.
subQuotationList: ["I won't have her dragged in, either; I won't have any more trouble\non my account,", 'Her evidence is not the least essential.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I thought she would want to give it. No one blames you, mother,
but the fact remains that you dropped off at the first cave, and
encouraged Adela to go on with him alone, whereas if you'd been
well enough to keep on too nothing would have happened. He planned
it, I know. Still, you fell into his trap just like Fielding and
Antony before you. . . . Forgive me for speaking so plainly, but
you've no right to take up this high and mighty attitude about law
courts. If you're ill, that's different; but you say you're all
right and you seem so, in which case I thought you'ld want to take
your part, I did really.
subQuotationList:
["I thought she would want to give it. No one blames you, mother,
but the fact remains that you dropped off at the first cave, and
encouraged Adela to go on with him alone, whereas if you'd been
well enough to keep on too nothing would have happened. He planned
it, I know. Still, you fell into his trap just like Fielding and
Antony before you. . . . Forgive me for speaking so plainly, but
you've no right to take up this high and mighty attitude about law
courts. If you're ill, that's different; but you say you're all
right and you seem so, in which case I thought you'ld want to take
your part, I did really."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Adela Quested'], ['Dr. Aziz'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Dr. Aziz'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Dr. Aziz'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Antony'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore']]]

quoteText: I'll not have you worry her whether she's well or ill,
subQuotationList: ["I'll not have you worry her whether she's well or ill,"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: I shall attend your marriage, but not your trial, Then I shall go to England.
subQuotationList: ['I shall attend your marriage, but not your trial,', 'Then I shall go to England.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: You can't go to England in May, as you agreed.
subQuotationList: ["You can't go to England in May, as you agreed."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I have changed my mind.
subQuotationList: ['I have changed my mind.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Well, we'd better end this unexpected wrangle, You appear to want to be left out of
everything, and that's enough.
subQuotationList: ["Well, we'd better end this unexpected wrangle,", "You appear to want to be left out of\neverything, and that's enough."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
My body, my miserable body, Why isn't it strong?
Oh, why can't I walk away and be gone? Why can't I finish my duties
and be gone? Why do I get headaches and puff when I walk? And all
the time this to do and that to do and this to do in your way and
that to do in her way, and everything sympathy and confusion and
bearing one another's burdens. Why can't this be done and that be
done in my way and they be done and I at peace? Why has anything
to be done, I cannot see. Why all this marriage, marriage? . . .
The human race would have become a single person centuries ago if
marriage was any use. And all this rubbish about love, love in a
church, love in a cave, as if there is the least difference, and
I held up from my business over such trifles!
subQuotationList:
['My body, my miserable body,', "Why isn't it strong?
Oh, why can't I walk away and be gone? Why can't I finish my duties
and be gone? Why do I get headaches and puff when I walk? And all
the time this to do and that to do and this to do in your way and
that to do in her way, and everything sympathy and confusion and
bearing one another's burdens. Why can't this be done and that be
done in my way and they be done and I at peace? Why has anything
to be done, I cannot see. Why all this marriage, marriage? . . .
The human race would have become a single person centuries ago if
marriage was any use. And all this rubbish about love, love in a
church, love in a cave, as if there is the least difference, and
I held up from my business over such trifles!"]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
What do you want? Can you state it in
simple language? If so, do.
subQuotationList: ['What do you want?', 'Can you state it in\nsimple language? If so, do.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I want my pack of patience cards.
subQuotationList: ['I want my pack of patience cards.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Very well, get them.
subQuotationList: ['Very well, get them.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Well, my dear girl, this isn't much of a home-coming, I had no idea she had this up her sleeve.
subQuotationList: ["Well, my dear girl, this isn't much of a home-coming,", 'I had no idea she had this up her sleeve.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Aziz, Aziz.
subQuotationList: ['Aziz, Aziz.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Aziz . . . have I made a mistake?
subQuotationList: ['Aziz . . . have I made a mistake?']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: You're over-tired,
subQuotationList: ["You're over-tired,"]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Ronny, he's innocent; I made an awful mistake.
subQuotationList: ["Ronny, he's innocent; I made an awful mistake."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Well, sit down anyhow.
subQuotationList: ['Well, sit down anyhow.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: My echo's better.
subQuotationList: ["My echo's better."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
That's good. You'll be perfectly well in a few days, but you must
save yourself up for the trial. Das is a very good fellow, we shall
all be with you.
subQuotationList: ["That's good. You'll be perfectly well in a few days, but you must\nsave yourself up for the trial. Das is a very good fellow, we shall\nall be with you."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: But Ronny, dear Ronny, perhaps there oughtn't to be any trial.
subQuotationList: ["But Ronny, dear Ronny, perhaps there oughtn't to be any trial."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: I don't quite know what you're saying, and I don't think you do.
subQuotationList: ["I don't quite know what you're saying, and I don't think you do."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: If Dr. Aziz never did it he ought to be let out.
subQuotationList: ['If Dr. Aziz never did it he ought to be let out.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
He was let out   until the Mohurram riot, when he had to be put in
again.
subQuotationList: ['He was let out   until the Mohurram riot, when he had to be put in\nagain.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Half a minute,
subQuotationList: ['Half a minute,']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Help me to do what
I ought. Aziz is good. You heard your mother say so.
subQuotationList: ['Help me to do what\nI ought. Aziz is good. You heard your mother say so.']
speaker: Adela Quested
referringExpression: she clung to him and sobbed

quoteText: Heard what?
subQuotationList: ['Heard what?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: He's good; I've been so wrong to accuse him.
subQuotationList: ["He's good; I've been so wrong to accuse him."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Mother never said so.
subQuotationList: ['Mother never said so.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Didn't she?
subQuotationList: ["Didn't she?"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: She never mentioned that name once.
subQuotationList: ['She never mentioned that name once.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: But, Ronny, I heard her.
subQuotationList: ['But, Ronny, I heard her.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
Pure illusion. You can't be quite well, can you, to make up a
thing like that.
subQuotationList: ["Pure illusion. You can't be quite well, can you, to make up a\nthing like that."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I suppose I can't. How amazing of me!
subQuotationList: ["I suppose I can't. How amazing of me!"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I was listening to all she said, as far as it could be listened
to; she gets very incoherent.
subQuotationList: ['I was listening to all she said, as far as it could be listened\nto; she gets very incoherent.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
When her voice dropped she said it   towards the end, when she
talked about love   love   I couldn't follow, but just then she said:
   Doctor Aziz never did it.'
subQuotationList: ["When her voice dropped she said it   towards the end, when she\ntalked about love   love   I couldn't follow, but just then she said:\n   Doctor Aziz never did it.'"]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Those words?
subQuotationList: ['Those words?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: The idea more than the words.
subQuotationList: ['The idea more than the words.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
Never, never, my dear girl. Complete illusion. His name was not
mentioned by anyone. Look here   you are confusing this with
Fielding's letter.
subQuotationList: ["Never, never, my dear girl. Complete illusion. His name was not\nmentioned by anyone. Look here   you are confusing this with\nFielding's letter."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
That's it, that's it, I knew I'd
heard his name somewhere. I am so grateful to you for clearing this
up   it's the sort of mistake that worries me, and proves I'm
neurotic.
subQuotationList:
["That's it, that's it,", "I knew I'd
heard his name somewhere. I am so grateful to you for clearing this
up   it's the sort of mistake that worries me, and proves I'm
neurotic."]
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
So you won't go saying he's innocent again, will you? for every
servant I've got is a spy.
subQuotationList: ["So you won't go saying he's innocent again, will you? for every\nservant I've got is a spy."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
They all hate us, It'll be all right after the verdict, for I will
say this for them, they do accept the accomplished fact; but at
present they're pouring out money like water to catch us tripping,
and a remark like yours is the very thing they look out for. It
would enable them to say it was a put-up job on the part of us
officials. You see what I mean.
subQuotationList:
['They all hate us,', "It'll be all right after the verdict, for I will
say this for them, they do accept the accomplished fact; but at
present they're pouring out money like water to catch us tripping,
and a remark like yours is the very thing they look out for. It
would enable them to say it was a put-up job on the part of us
officials. You see what I mean."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I never said his name,
subQuotationList: ['I never said his name,']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: I thought you said,

quoteText:
but it was in Mr.
Fielding's letter.

quoteText: Of course he is innocent,

speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: You see, Ronny, I was right,
subQuotationList: ['You see, Ronny, I was right,']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: You were not right, she never said it.
subQuotationList: ['You were not right, she never said it.']

quoteText: But she thinks it.

speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Who cares what she thinks?
subQuotationList: ['Who cares what she thinks?']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Red nine on black ten
subQuotationList: ['Red nine on black ten']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
She can think, and Fielding too, but there's such a thing as
evidence, I suppose.
subQuotationList: ["She can think, and Fielding too, but there's such a thing as\nevidence, I suppose."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: I know, but
subQuotationList: ['I know, but']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText: Is it again my duty to talk? Apparently, as you keep interrupting me.
subQuotationList: ['Is it again my duty to talk?', 'Apparently, as you keep interrupting me.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Only if you have anything sensible to say.
subQuotationList: ['Only if you have anything sensible to say.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Oh, how tedious . . . trivial . . .
subQuotationList: ['Oh, how tedious . . . trivial . . .']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
Oh, why is everything still
my duty? when shall I be free from your fuss? Was he in the cave
and were you in the cave and on and on . . . and Unto us a Son is
born, unto us a Child is given . . . and am I good and is he bad
and are we saved? . . . and ending everything the echo.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, why is everything still
my duty? when shall I be free from your fuss? Was he in the cave
and were you in the cave and on and on . . . and Unto us a Son is
born, unto us a Child is given . . . and am I good and is he bad
and are we saved? . . . and ending everything the echo.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText:
I don't hear it so much, You
send it away, you do nothing but good, you are so good.
subQuotationList: ["I don't hear it so much,", 'You\nsend it away, you do nothing but good, you are so good.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
I am not good, no, bad. A bad old woman, bad, bad,
detestable. I used to be good with the children growing up, also
I meet this young man in his mosque, I wanted him to be happy.
Good, happy, small people. They do not exist, they were a dream.
. . . But I will not help you to torture him for what he never did.
There are different ways of evil and I prefer mine to yours.
subQuotationList:
['I am not good, no, bad.', 'A bad old woman, bad, bad,
detestable. I used to be good with the children growing up, also
I meet this young man in his mosque, I wanted him to be happy.
Good, happy, small people. They do not exist, they were a dream.
. . . But I will not help you to torture him for what he never did.
There are different ways of evil and I prefer mine to yours.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore
referringExpression: She spoke more calmly and resumed her cards saying

quoteText:
Have you any evidence in the prisoner's favour? If so, it is your bounden duty to
go into the witness-box for him instead of for us. No one will stop
you.
subQuotationList: ["Have you any evidence in the prisoner's favour?", 'If so, it is your bounden duty to\ngo into the witness-box for him instead of for us. No one will stop\nyou.']

quoteText:
One knows people's characters, as you call them, I have heard both English and Indians speak well
of him, and I felt it isn't the sort of thing he would do.
subQuotationList: ["One knows people's characters, as you call them,", "I have heard both English and Indians speak well\nof him, and I felt it isn't the sort of thing he would do."]
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: Feeble, mother, feeble.
subQuotationList: ['Feeble, mother, feeble.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText: Most feeble.
subQuotationList: ['Most feeble.']
speaker: Mrs. Moore

quoteText: And most inconsiderate to Adela.
subQuotationList: ['And most inconsiderate to Adela.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
It would be so appalling if I was wrong. I should take
my own life.
subQuotationList: ['It would be so appalling if I was wrong. I should take\nmy own life.']
speaker: Adela Quested

quoteText:
What was I warning you just now? You know
you're right, and the whole station knows it.
subQuotationList: ["What was I warning you just now? You know\nyou're right, and the whole station knows it."]
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
Yes, he . . . This is very, very awful. I'm as certain as ever he
followed me . . . only, wouldn't it be possible to withdraw the
case? I dread the idea of giving evidence more and more, and you
are all so good to women here and you have so much more power than
in England   look at Miss Derek's motor-car. Oh, of course it's out
of the question, I'm ashamed to have mentioned it; please forgive
me.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, he . . . This is very, very awful. I'm as certain as ever he
followed me . . . only, wouldn't it be possible to withdraw the

me."]

subQuotationList: ["That's all right,", 'Of course I forgive you,\nas you call it. But the case has to come before a magistrate now;\nit really must, the machinery has started.']
speaker: Ronny Heaslop

quoteText:
and if it had, if it had, there are worse evils
than love.
subQuotationList: ['and if it had,', 'if it had, there are worse evils\nthan love.']

Less attention should
be paid to my future daughter-in-law and more to me, there is no

I
have not seen the right places,

subQuotationList: ['Half a minute,']

quoteText:
I bring you nothing but trouble; I was right on the

inclined.

right?

quoteText: Drink it up; not a bad notion, a peg.
subQuotationList: ['Drink it up; not a bad notion, a peg.']

My echo

quoteText: You won't,

quoteText: Of course she won't, she's a real sport.

quoteText:
If I do break down, it is of no consequence. It would matter in
some trials, not in this. I put it to myself in the following way:
I can really behave as I like, cry, be absurd, I am sure to get my
verdict, unless Mr. Das is most frightfully unjust.

innocent

Really,
after Mohurram a show of force will do no harm; it's ridiculous to
pretend they don't hate us, do give up that farce.

quoteText:
Swine, I should think so, And what's more,
I'll tell you what. What's happened is a damn good thing really,
barring of course its application to present company. It'll make
them squeal and it's time they did squeal. I've put the fear of
God into them at the hospital anyhow. You should see the grandson
of our so-called leading loyalist.

I'll tell you what. What's happened is a damn good thing really,

Old Panna Lal brought him the looking-glass yesterday and he

you; that used to be one of these buck niggers, I thought, now he's

immoral   er I wish
I'd had the cutting up of my late assistant too; nothing's too bad
for these people.

a thing like this.

quoteText:
Exactly, and remember it afterwards, you men. You're weak, weak,
weak. Why, they ought to crawl from here to the caves on their
hands and knees whenever an Englishwoman's in sight, they oughtn't
to be spoken to, they ought to be spat at, they ought to be ground
into the dust, we've been far too kind with our Bridge Parties and
the rest.

quoteText:
Excuse me We object to the presence of so many European
ladies and gentlemen upon the platform, They will have the effect of intimidating our witnesses.
Their place is with the rest of the public in the body of the hall.
We have no objection to Miss Quested remaining on the platform,
since she has been unwell; we shall extend every courtesy to her
throughout, despite the scientific truths revealed to us by the
District Superintendent of Police; but we do object to the others.

quoteText:
I have nothing to add at
present, I will now call
my witnesses. The facts will speak for themselves. The prisoner is
one of those individuals who have led a double life. I dare say
his degeneracy gained upon him gradually. He has been very cunning
at concealing, as is usual with the type, and pretending to be a
respectable member of society, getting a Government position even.
He is now entirely vicious and beyond redemption, I am afraid. He
behaved most cruelly, most brutally, to another of his guests,
another English lady. In order to get rid of her, and leave him
free for his crime, he crushed her into a cave among his servants.
However, that is by the way.
subQuotationList:
['I have nothing to add at
present,', 'I will now call
my witnesses. The facts will speak for themselves. The prisoner is
one of those individuals who have led a double life. I dare say
his degeneracy gained upon him gradually. He has been very cunning
at concealing, as is usual with the type, and pretending to be a
respectable member of society, getting a Government position even.
He is now entirely vicious and beyond redemption, I am afraid. He
behaved most cruelly, most brutally, to another of his guests,
another English lady. In order to get rid of her, and leave him
free for his crime, he crushed her into a cave among his servants.
However, that is by the way.']

quoteText:
She was kept from us until too late   I learn too late   this is
English justice, here is your British Raj. Give us back Mrs. Moore
for five minutes only, and she will save my friend, she will save
the name of his sons; don't rule her out, Mr. Das; take back those
words as you yourself are a father; tell me where they have put
her, oh, Mrs. Moore. . . .

quoteText:
Exactly, sir, he must. But we had just learnt that Mrs. Moore had
important evidence which she desired to give. She was hurried out
of the country by her son before she could give it; and this
unhinged Mr. Mahmoud Ali   coming as it does upon an attempt to
intimidate our only other European witness, Mr. Fielding. Mr.
Mahmoud Ali would have said nothing had not Mrs. Moore been claimed
as a witness by the police.
subQuotationList:
['Exactly, sir, he must. But we had just learnt that Mrs. Moore had
important evidence which she desired to give. She was hurried out
of the country by her son before she could give it; and this
unhinged Mr. Mahmoud Ali   coming as it does upon an attempt to
intimidate our only other European witness, Mr. Fielding. Mr.
Mahmoud Ali would have said nothing had not Mrs. Moore been claimed
as a witness by the police.']
speaker: Mr. Amritrao
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'The Nawab Badahur', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Miss Derek', 'Mr. Mcbryde']
mentionTextsList: [['sir', 'he', 'we', 'Mrs. Moore', 'she', 'She', 'her son', 'she', 'our only other European witness', 'Mr. Fielding', 'Mr.\nMahmoud Ali', 'Mrs. Moore']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Das'], ['Mahmoud Ali'], ['Mr. Amritrao', 'Mahmoud Ali'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Ronny Heaslop'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Cyril Fielding'], ['Mahmoud Ali'], ['Mrs. Moore']]]

quoteText:
An extraneous element is being introduced into the case, I must repeat that as a witness Mrs. Moore does
not exist. Neither you, Mr. Amritrao, nor, Mr. McBryde, you, have
any right to surmise what that lady would have said. She is not
here, and consequently she can say nothing.
subQuotationList:
['An extraneous element is being introduced into the case,', 'I must repeat that as a witness Mrs. Moore does
not exist. Neither you, Mr. Amritrao, nor, Mr. McBryde, you, have
any right to surmise what that lady would have said. She is not
here, and consequently she can say nothing.']
speaker: Mr. Das
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'The Nawab Badahur', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek', 'Mr. Mcbryde']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mr. Amritrao'], ['Mr. Amritrao'], ['Mr. Mcbryde'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore'], ['Mrs. Moore']]]

quoteText:
Well, I withdraw my reference, I would have done so fifteen minutes ago if I had been given the
chance. She is not of the least importance to me.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I withdraw my reference,', 'I would have done so fifteen minutes ago if I had been given the\nchance. She is not of the least importance to me.']
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'The Nawab Badahur', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek']

quoteText:
I have already withdrawn it for the defence. Perhaps you can persuade the gentlemen outside
to withdraw it too,
subQuotationList: ['I have already withdrawn it for the defence.', 'Perhaps you can persuade the gentlemen outside\nto withdraw it too,']
speaker: Mr. Amritrao
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'The Nawab Badahur', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Miss Derek', 'Mr. Mcbryde']

quoteText: I am afraid my powers do not extend so far,
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid my powers do not extend so far,']
speaker: Mr. Das
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'The Nawab Badahur', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek', 'Mr. Mcbryde']

quoteText:
. . . the prisoner and the guide took you on to the Kawa Dol, no
one else being present?
subQuotationList: ['. . . the prisoner and the guide took you on to the Kawa Dol, no\none else being present?']
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'The Nawab Badahur', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek']

quoteText: The most wonderfully shaped of those hills. Yes. No one else was present to my knowledge. We appeared to be alone.
subQuotationList: ['The most wonderfully shaped of those hills. Yes.', 'No one else was present to my knowledge. We appeared to be alone.']
speaker: Adela Quested
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek', 'Mr. Mcbryde']

quoteText:
Very well, there is a ledge half-way up the hill, or broken ground
rather, with caves scattered near the beginning of a nullah.
subQuotationList: ['Very well, there is a ledge half-way up the hill, or broken ground\nrather, with caves scattered near the beginning of a nullah.']
speaker: Mr. Mcbryde
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'The Nawab Badahur', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek']

quoteText: I know where you mean.
subQuotationList: ['I know where you mean.']
speaker: Adela Quested
addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek', 'Mr. Mcbryde']

quoteText: You went alone into one of those caves?

addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Adela Quested', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'The Nawab Badahur', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek']

quoteText: That is quite correct.

addressees: ['Cyril Fielding', 'Ronny Heaslop', 'Mrs. Turton', 'Major Callendar', 'Mr. Das', 'Mr. Turton', 'Mahmoud Ali', 'Mrs. Lesley', 'Dr. Aziz', 'Mrs. Mcbryde', 'Mr. Amritrao', 'Miss Derek', 'Mr. Mcbryde']

You are on that landing, or whatever we term it, and you
have entered a cave. I suggest to you that the prisoner followed
you.

quoteText: No,

quoteText: Dr. Aziz never followed me into the cave.
